text: Hi All! I've been a CMM for almost four years now with the same company. I've grown my team in that time and now have four writers that I assign work to. In the beginning, I was making assignment decisions off of keyword research, sales calls, and blog performance. Now it's turned into my team taking requests from other marketing team members to create their ad copy, email copy, landing page copy, direct mail copy, blog announcements, etc. It feels.... like not the best use of my team's time. However, if that's what's best for the business - we'll stay on course. My question is - how often are you creating content for other marketing team members? Or - alternatively - are you able to determine your teams priorities and just review the work of other team members instead? I'd love to hear how other content teams function so I can better inform our leadership and set our team in the right direction.

text:
our marketing team (~5-10 people, depending on how you count it) has been on-off with weekly/twice-weekly sprint meetings over the last 1.5 yrs.

protecting the time/focusing the work of the ~3 people on the content team has really benefited from _having_ those meetings.

otherwise, there are too many ad hoc requests from senior people in the company to those on the content team who may be hesitant to push back or simply don't have the full picture of what matters most to content, marketing, or the company.

getting everyone together, even for 15 minutes a week, creates an opportunity for me to protect their time (in some cases) or confirm the importance/opportunity cost of shifting their time  (in other cases).

those sprints also help with visibility by getting all projects on a trello board. some asks no longer come simply because someone can see all the other stuff someone's working on.

text:
<@U013P4Q9YTU> I totally feel you on this! We don’t get some of the more copywriting oriented requests (e.g. ad copy) but we get a lot of requests initiated as “I am doing a major project and we want to put it on the blog.” What I do with those is ask the requestor to tell me the overall goal of their project. If the blog is a good channel to support that, and the project is a shared priority, our team will usually take on everything except writing the blog post (e.g. SEO research, editing, getting artwork, editing/feedback) but we’ll ask the driver of the project to write the piece themselves. That work will be accounted for in one of the writer’s monthly bandwidth. If the goal of the project isn’t aligned to our team’s goals, I do a little more digging--why a blog post? What are you trying to achieve? etc. and typically make an alternative recommendation for other marketing channels they can tap.

I also try to leave some flexibility in our content planning, which happens quarterly, to accomodate a couple of those requests popping up last minute.

Big picture though, if these things are valuable to other team members and to your marketing goals, and team members truly don’t have the skill to do these effectively themselves, I’d look at the themes in requests you’re getting and decide if it’s worth pitching an additional team member focused on copywriting--who wouldn’t have articles assigned but is more honing that craft.
